snippet: The addition of Eid al-Fitr and Eid al-Adha to the calendar fulfills a campaign pledge from Mayor Bill de Blasio and represents the increasing influence of the city’s Muslim community.
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio, fulfilling campaign pledge, announces that New York City will close public schools in observance of Eid al-Fitr and Eid al-Adha, two of the most important Muslim holidays; policy, first in any major American city, comes at time when Muslim-Americans are facing more scrutiny after terrorist attacks in Europe and violence in the Middle East.

byline.original: By MICHAEL M. GRYNBAUM and SHARON OTTERMAN
byline.contributor: Elizabeth A. Harris, Louisa Reynolds and Marc Santora contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: The addition of Eid al-Fitr and Eid al-Adha to the calendar fulfills a campaign pledge from Mayor Bill de Blasio and represents the increasing influence of the city’s Muslim community.

headline.main: New York City Adds 2 Muslim Holy Days to Public School Calendar
headline.print_headline: New York Schools Closing for 2 Muslim Holidays
